revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=August 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Jo Brand | image = Jo Brand Award.jpg | caption = Brand at the [[Immediate Media Company|BBC Magazines]]
Awards for Excellence, 2007 | birth_name = Josephine Grace Brand RMN h.c | birth_place = England | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1957|07|23}} | nationality = [[British nationality law|British]] | spouse = Bernie Bourke {{Smaller|(m. 1997)}} | medium = {{Hlist | [[Stand up comedian|Stand-up]] | [[Television]] | [[Film]] }} | active = 1986–present | genre = {{Hlist | [[Observational comedy|Observational]] | [[Alternative comedy|Alternative]] }} | subject = {{Hlist | [[Marriage]] | [[Politics]] }} | children = 2 }} '''Josephine Grace Brand''' (born 23 July 1957) is an English comedian, writer and actress.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/the-interview-jo-brand-comedian-talks-to-1322733.html|title=the interview JO BRAND, COMEDIAN, TALKS TO|last=Thompson|first=Ben|work=[[The Independent]]|date=23 October 2011|accessdate=3 November 2015}} Starting her entertainment career with a move from [[Psychiatric and mental health nursing|psychiatric nursing]] to the [[alternative comedy]] stand-up scene and early performances on ''[[Saturday Live (UK TV series)|Saturday Live]]'', she went on to appear on ''[[The Brain Drain]]'', [[Channel 4]]'s ''[[Jo Brand Through the Cakehole]]'', ''[[Getting On (UK TV series)|Getting On]]'' and various television appearances including as a regular guest on ''[[QI]]'', ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'' and ''[[Would I Lie to You? (TV series)|Would I Lie to You?]]''. She is currently the presenter of ''[[The Great British Bake Off: An Extra Slice]]''. In 2003, Brand was listed in ''[[The Observer]]'' as one of the 50 funniest acts in British comedy. ==Early life== Brand was born in Hastings, East Sussex. Her mother was a [[social worker]] and her father was a [[structural engineer]]. Brand is the middle of three children, with two brothers. When she was about four, the family moved to the village of [[St Mary's Platt]] near [[Sevenoaks]] in [[Kent]], and a year later, to [[Benenden]]. Brand was educated at St Mary's Platt Primary School, Benenden Village Primary School, [[Tunbridge Wells Girls' Grammar School]] until the age of 16, [[Helenswood School|Hastings High School for Girls]] and [[Bexhill College]]. After working in a pub, for [[Barnardo's]] and as a nursing assistant in a residential unit for adults with learning disabilities she took a joint social science degree with a [[Nursing in the United Kingdom|Registered Mental Nurse]] qualification at [[Brunel University]]. She then worked as a [[psychiatric nurse]] for ten years, at the [[Bethlem Royal Hospital|South London Bethlem]], [[Cefn Coed Hospital]] in [[Swansea]] and [[Maudsley Hospital]] in south London.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=hxRMDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA162&lpg=PA162|title=Clinical Leadership in Nursing and Healthcare: Values into Action|first=David|last=Stanley|date=19 October 2016|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|accessdate=8 May 2018|via=Google Books}} ==Career== ===Comedy=== Brand was persuaded by agent [[Malcolm Hardee]] to begin a career in stand-up comedy, where she acquired the stage name the "Sea Monster". She was part of the British [[alternative comedy]] movement, working in London alternative comedy clubs in the mid-1980s, and appearing initially on the ''[[Saturday Live (UK TV series)|Saturday Live]]'' television show. She shared a flat with fellow comic and comedy club owner [[Ivor Dembina]].{{cite book|last1=Brand|first1=Jo|title=Can't Stand Up for Sitting Down|date=2010|publisher=Headline Review|location=London|isbn=978-0755355266}} During her first gig, she faced "an audience from hell" and, waiting to perform last, drank seven pints of lager. She thus faced her first live audience with a bursting bladder. As Brand ascended the stage, a male heckler started shouting, "Fuck off, you fat cow" and kept up the abuse until her performance finished. There was no applause at the end of her act. Brand's early style involved her delivering jokes in a bored monotone, one line at a time, with pauses in between. It drew heavily from pop culture and the media, with many jokes containing references to well-known celebrities and public figures. With her [[Doc Marten]] boots, her large size, and her short hair, her image remained the same for most of the 1980s and 1990s. Her appearance and material led to false rumours that she was a [[lesbian]].[http://www.bbc.co.uk/coventry/content/articles/2005/10/26/jo_brand_review_feature.shtml "Jo Brand is one funny woman"], BBC interview, 26 October 2005 (viewed 9 July 2009) [[File:Jo Brand 1994.jpg|thumb|upright|Jo Brand in 1994 in [[Belfast]]]] In 2007, Brand narrated ''Laughter & Tears: The Les Dawson Story'', a documentary tribute to [[Les Dawson]], which was broadcast on [[BBC Radio 2]] in October 2007. In 2010, Brand took part in ''[[Channel 4's Comedy Gala]]'', a [[Benefit concert|benefit show]] held in aid of [[Great Ormond Street Hospital|Great Ormond Street Children's Hospital]], filmed live at the [[The O2 Arena (London)|O2 Arena]] in London on 30 March. Brand played the Demon Dinner Lady in the 2011 [[British cinema|British]] live-action film ''[[Horrid Henry the Movie]]''. She also provided a voiceover for the Lyric Hammersmith Theatre's 2011 pantomime Aladdin. In August 2015, Brand judged the first ever Class Clowns competition at the [[Edinburgh Fringe Festival]], she also announced the winner at the [[Gilded Balloon]] on the night. Brand has written a feature-film adaptation to her novel ''The More You Ignore Me''. She will also star in the film. ===Television=== In 1993, Brand became a resident panellist, along with [[Tony Hawks]], on BBC monologue show ''[[The Brain Drain]]''. Her transition into mainstream television continued when she starred in her own series on [[Channel 4]], ''[[Jo Brand Through the Cakehole]]'', co-written with comedy writer Jim Miller, who was already her main stand-up writer. Brand has had several solo television series, and presented shows such as ''[[Commercial Breakdown|Jo Brand's Commercial Breakdown]]''. She had a [[cameo appearance|cameo]] appearance in a 1994 episode of ''[[Absolutely Fabulous]]'' entitled "New Best Friend", and also appeared on ''[[Star Spell]]'', a spin-off from ''[[Hard Spell]]'' in 2004. Her television success continued with guest appearances on shows such as ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'' and ''[[QI]]'', to the extent where she became the most frequently appearing guest on the latter, appearing in a total of 34 episodes. As a fan of ''[[Countdown (game show)|Countdown]]'', Brand achieved an ambition when she was invited to appear in the show's "Dictionary Corner" as the celebrity guest. She later became a friend of the host, [[Richard Whiteley]], and after his death in 2005 attended his [[funeral|memorial service]] at [[York Minster]]. She has appeared on ''Countdown'' as a Dictionary Corner guest 88 times.{{cite web|title=Jo Brand - Countdown|url=http://wiki.apterous.org/Jo_Brand|website=Apterous Wiki|accessdate=27 May 2017}} In 2004, Brand appeared in a special episode of ''[[What Not to Wear (UK)|What Not to Wear]]'', where fashion gurus [[Trinny Woodall]] and [[Susannah Constantine]] gave her a makeover. On 25 March 2007, Brand appeared on ''[[Play It Again]]'' where she was required to learn how to play the [[organ (music)|organ]] in just four months. This was in preparation to perform [[Johann Sebastian Bach]]'s [[Toccata and Fugue in D minor, BWV 565|Toccata and Fugue in D Minor]] for an audience of 8,000 people at London's [[Royal Albert Hall]] on the second largest [[pipe organ]] in the United Kingdom. In order to practise her performance, she played [[Dear Lord and Father of Mankind]] – a favourite hymn of hers at a church service in her former village church in Benenden, Kent, and accompanied dancers at [[Blackpool Tower]]. Prior to this, her only experiences with musical instruments had been childhood piano and violin lessons.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/playitagain/programmes/series1/jobrand/ ''Play it Again''] BBC Television Brand took part in the first celebrity version of ''[[Comic Relief Does Fame Academy]]''. In 2007, she appeared as a celebrity contestant on ''[[Comic Relief Does The Apprentice]]''. In 2009, she participated in ''[[Let's Dance for Comic Relief]]'', another Comic Relief fundraiser, dancing as [[Britney Spears]], reaching the final. She has also been a judge on the show. In January 2013, Brand took part in a special Comic Relief series of ''[[The Great British Bake Off]]''. Brand has been a fill-in host on ''[[The Paul O'Grady Show]]'' and ''[[The One Show]]''. Brand co-created, co-wrote and co-starred in the [[BBC Four]] sitcom ''[[Getting On (UK TV series)|Getting On]]'' opposite [[Joanna Scanlan]] and [[Vicki Pepperdine]], for which she won the 2011 Best TV Comedy Actress BAFTA award. The series, directed by [[Peter Capaldi]] and [[Sue Tully]], is a gritty and realistic satire on the current state of the [[National Health Service|NHS]], set in a geriatric ward. In April 2009, Brand was as a judge with [[John Amaechi]] and Jeremy Stockwell on the [[BBC Two]] series ''[[The Speaker]]'', charting the search for "Britain's Best Young Speaker".[http://www.bbc.co.uk/speaker/improve/fear Fighting the Fear], ''The Speaker'', BBC Television In 2011, Brand presented ''[[Jo Brand's Big Splash]]'', a television programme where she performed a stand-up routine and visited people with a love of water and it was produced by her production company, What Larks! Productions. {{cite web|url=http://www.whatlarks.tv/Big_Splash.html|title=Big Splash|publisher=What Larks! Productions|accessdate=20 June 2012}} {{cite web|url=http://www.whatlarks.tv/about-us.html|title=About Us|publisher=What Larks! Productions|accessdate=20 June 2012}} In January 2013 and 2014, Brand was a judge with Andy Banks and [[Leon Taylor]] on the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] show ''[[Splash! (UK TV series)|Splash!]]'' . On 14 January 2014, Brand presented an episode of ''The Great Sport Relief Bake Off'' on [[BBC Two]], a charity version of ''[[The Great British Bake Off]]''. In February 2015, she also presented an episode of ''The Great Comic Relief Bake Off''. She is the presenter of ''[[The Great British Bake Off: An Extra Slice]]'', which premiered on 8 August 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2014/07/23/20618/jo_brand_to_front_bake-off_spin-off|title=Jo Brand to front Bake-Off spin-off : News 2014 : Chortle : The UK Comedy Guide|publisher=Chortle|date=23 July 2014|accessdate=29 July 2014}} A second series aired from August 2015, third from August 2016 and a fourth from August 2017. In 2014, Brand co-wrote and starred as Rose in a comedy pilot for [[Sky Arts]] called ''[[Damned (TV series)|Damned]]''. The show was commissioned for a full series by [[Channel 4]], airing in 2016; its second series aired in 2018. Since 2017, she has presented the [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]] series ''Jo Brand's Cats & Kittens''. ==Bibliography== ; Novels * ''Mental'' (with [[Helen Griffin]]. HTV Sherman Plays series. Cardiff: Drama Association of Wales, 1996). {{ISBN|1-898740-41-0}} * ''Sorting Out Billy''{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2004/jun/14/digestedread.theeditorpressreview7|title=The digested read: Sorting Out Billy by Jo Brand|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=6 August 2009|location=London|date=14 June 2004}} (novel. London: Review, 2004). {{ISBN|0-7553-2336-X}} * ''It's Different for Girls'' (novel. London: Headline Review, 2005). {{ISBN|0-7553-2229-0}} * ''The More You Ignore Me'' (novel. London: Headline Review, 2009). {{ISBN|0-7553-2231-2}} ; Autobiographies * ''Look Back in Hunger. The Autobiography'' (London: Headline Review, 2009). {{ISBN|0-7553-5525-3}} * ''Can't Stand Up For Sitting Down. The Autobiography – Part 2'' (London: Headline Review, 2010). {{ISBN|978-0-7553-5526-6}} ; Non fiction * ''A Load of Old Balls: Men in History'' (London: Simon & Schuster, 1994). {{ISBN|0-671-71385-X}} * ''A Load of Old Ball Crunchers: Women in History'' (London: Simon & Schuster, 1996). {{ISBN|0-684-81695-4}} ==Personal life== [[File:Jo Brand Garden.jpg|thumb|160px|Brand at Bonkers Fest 2007]] Brand married Bernie Bourke, a psychiatric nurse, in 1997{{cite news|last=McSmith|first=Andy|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/jo-brand-a-softer-brand-of-humour-1570724.html|title=Jo Brand: A softer brand of humour|publisher=Independent.co.uk|date=7 February 2009|accessdate=30 January 2014}} in [[Shropshire]]. They have two daughters, Maisie and Eliza.{{cite web|author=Nick McGrath|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2013/dec/13/jo-brand-comedian-my-family-values|title=Jo Brand: My family values|publisher=The Guardian|date=2013-12-13|accessdate=2018-04-05}} Brand delivered a guest lecture on the subject of [[psychiatric nursing]] for the [[University of Derby]] Psychology Society in 1997 in return for a donation to Derby Rape Crisis. Also in 1997, she opened, at [[Lambeth Hospital]] in [[South London]], the first major exhibition of the Adamson Collection since the death of [[Edward Adamson]], the pioneer of Art Therapy, in 1996. In February 2009, Brand was among a group of British entertainers who wrote an open letter to ''[[The Times]]'' of London in support of the [[Bahá'í]] leaders who were then on trial in [[Iran]].[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/letters/article5804284.ece "Stand up for Iran’s Baha’is"] Open letter to ''The Times'', 26 February 2009 (viewed 9 July 2009) ===Charity=== Brand is a supporter of the charity [[ActionAid]] and has taken part in fundraising events for the organisation. {{Cite news|title=Jo Brand, Meera Syal, and Nicholas Owen join Clive Anderson for Call My Wine Bluff|url=http://www.actionaid.org.uk/103029/jo_brand_meera_syal_and_nicholas_owen_join_clive_anderson_for_call_my_wine_bluff.html|publisher=[[ActionAid UK]]|date=23 September 2011|accessdate=20 April 2012}} In November 2014, Brand was a part of [[Gareth Malone]]'s ''All Star Choir'',{{cite web|work=[[BBC]]|title=Gareth Malone forms an all-star choir for the Official BBC Children in Need single|date=2014|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/profiles/3GcB6pTQ6QpNLFKFy0RC8JP/gareth-malone-forms-an-all-star-choir-for-the-official-bbc-children-in-need-single}} who released a cover version of "[[Wake Me Up (Avicii song)|Wake Me Up]]" to raise money for the [[BBC]]'s [[Children in Need]].{{cite web|work=[[BBC]]|title=Gareth Malone to form All-Star Choir for official BBC Children in Need single 2014|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2014/gareth-malone-all-star-choir|date=24 September 2014}} On 28 January 2016, Brand completed a 150-mile walk across Britain, in aid of [[Sport Relief]], in [[Liverpool]]. Brand crossed the finish line at the [[Albert Dock]] at 7.30pm, having set off from the banks of the [[River Humber]] on 22 January.{{cite web |url=https://www.sportrelief.com/whats-going-on/jo-brands-hell-of-a-walk |title=Jo Brand's Hell of a Walk |publisher=Sport Relief |accessdate=9 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170111222440/https://www.sportrelief.com/whats-going-on/jo-brands-hell-of-a-walk |archivedate=11 January 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Her efforts were shown in a 60-minute documentary which aired on 17 March 2016, called ''[[Sport Relief 2016|Jo Brand's Hell of a Walk for Sport Relief]]''.{{cite web|author=Sam Dean |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/jo-brand-thanks-liverpool-rousing-10805471 |title=Jo Brand thanks Liverpool for rousing welcome as she finishes Sport Relief "Walk from Hell" |publisher=Liverpool Echo |date=29 January 2016 |accessdate=9 May 2017}} ===Politics=== Brand is a staunch supporter of the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gigglebeats.co.uk/2012/01/interview-jo-brand/|title=Interview: Jo Brand|date=23 January 2012|first=Andrew|last=Dipper|work=Giggle Beats}} She was still a contributor to and supporter of the party in 2012.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2010/feb/14/political-parties-celebrity-race|work=The Guardian|location=London|title=Parties in pre-election battle to sign up stars|first=Vanessa|last=Thorpe|date=14 February 2010|accessdate=6 May 2010}} Brand is a patron of the National Self Harm Network (NSHN), [[International Animal Rescue]], and the [[Prader-Willi Syndrome]] Association, as well as London Nightline. She is the president of the Ectopic Pregnancy Trust.{{cite web|url=http://www.ectopic.org.uk/index.php/trust/who-we-are/|title=Ectopic – Who we are|publisher=Ectopic.org.uk|date=25 October 2013|accessdate=30 January 2014}} Brand introduced and spoke at the celebration of [[Michael Foot]]'s life at London's Lyric Theatre, [[Shaftesbury Avenue]], on 8 November 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisplymouth.co.uk/news/just-great-man-really-good-man/article-2860136-detail/article.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120912062943/http://www.thisisplymouth.co.uk/news/just-great-man-really-good-man/article-2860136-detail/article.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=12 September 2012|title=Friends and supporters of the late Labour leader Michael Foot paid tribute to "a great leader" at a memorial service in his honour.|publisher=www.thisisplymouth.co.uk|accessdate=14 February 2011}} She is also a [[Republicanism in the United Kingdom|republican]].{{cn|date=June 2017}} In January 2012 she gave the [[South Shields]] annual lecture at [[Harton Technology College]] alongside the [[Member of Parliament|MP]] for the town, [[David Miliband]]. In August 2014, Brand was one of 200 public figures who were signatories to a letter to ''[[The Guardian]]'' opposing [[Scottish independence]] in the run-up to September's [[Scottish independence referendum, 2014|referendum on that issue]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/aug/07/celebrities-open-letter-scotland-independence-full-text|title=Celebrities' open letter to Scotland – full text and list of signatories | Politics|publisher=theguardian.com|date=7 August 2014|accessdate=26 August 2014}} Brand is a supporter of the [[Women's Equality Party]].{{cite AV media | people= [[Catherine Mayer]] (host), Jo Brand (guest) and [[Rosie Boycott]] (guest) | date= 3 April 2016 |accessdate= 28 April 2016 | title= Jo Brand & Rosie Boycott @ 5x15 - Women's Equality Party | medium= Video | publisher= 5x15 Stories via [[YouTube]] | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G7nFW9YmW_M }} ==Awards and honours== On 17 July 2007, Brand was awarded an [[Honorary degree|honorary doctorate]] for her work as a psychiatric nurse from the [[University of Glamorgan]] (now the [[University of South Wales]]). Professor Donna Mead, Dean of the School of Health, Sport and Science, who read Brand up for the award commented, "Jo incorporates much of her experience working in the field of mental health into her current work as a comedian. This has increased awareness of the work done by nurses in the mental health field. She has also used her experiences of working with individuals with conditions such as Alzheimer's to promote awareness of and raise funds for the Alzheimer's Society."[http://news.glam.ac.uk/news/en/2007/jul/17/glamorgan-honours/ "Glamorgan Honours"] University of Glamorgan, 17 July 2007 (viewed 15 July 2011) In December 2007 she received a ''Journal of Psychiatric and Mental Health Nursing'' Lifetime Achievement Award, an award associated with the [[Eileen Skellern]] Memorial Lecture. At this event she was praised for making mental health nursing more visible to the general public.{{cite web|url=http://www.skellern.info/2007.html|title=2007|website=www.skellern.info|accessdate=8 May 2018}} In January 2014, Brand was awarded a second honorary doctorate from [[Canterbury Christ Church University]], for her work in raising awareness of mental health issues and challenging the stigma surrounding such illnesses.{{cite web|last=Warren|first=Gerry|url=http://www.kentonline.co.uk/kentish_gazette/news/jo-brand-12020/|title=Comic Jo Brand honoured with honorary doctorate at Christ Church University in Canterbury|publisher=Kentonline.co.uk|date=29 January 2014|accessdate=30 January 2014}} ==Filmography== ;Television {| class="wikitable" style="border="2" |- style="text-align:center;" ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Notes |- | 1990 | ''[[Up Yer News]]'' | Herself | 2 episodes |- | 1992— | ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'' | Regular panellist/guest host | 18 appearances |- | 1994 | ''[[Absolutely Fabulous]]'' | Carmen | 1 episode |- | 1993–1996 | ''[[Jo Brand Through the Cakehole]]'' | Presenter | |- | 2003— | ''[[QI]]'' | Regular panellist | 36 appearances |- | 2009, 2013 | ''[[The Paul O'Grady Show]]'' | Stand-in presenter | 2 episodes |- | 2009 | ''[[The Speaker]]'' | Judge | |- | 2009–2012 | ''[[Getting On (UK TV series)|Getting On]]'' | Kim Wilde | Also written by Brand |- | rowspan=2|2011 | ''[[Jo Brand's Big Splash]]'' | Presenter | |- | ''[[Show Me the Funny]]'' | Guest judge | 1 episode |- | 2013–2014 | ''[[Splash! (UK TV series)|Splash!]]'' | Judge | |- | rowspan=2|2014 | ''[[The Great British Bake Off#The Great Sport/Comic Relief Bake Off|The Great Sport Relief Bake Off]]'' | Presenter | One episode (14 January) |- | ''[[The One Show]]'' | Stand-in presenter | Two episodes (17–18 March) |- | 2014, 2016— | ''[[Damned (TV series)|Damned]]''{{cite web|author=British Comedy Guide |url=https://www.comedy.co.uk/tv/news/2128/channel_4_orders_damned_series/ |title=Channel 4 to film Jo Brand and Alan Davies sitcom Damned - News - British Comedy Guide |publisher=Comedy.co.uk |date=25 May 2016 |accessdate=9 May 2017}} | Rose | 1 special (2014) and series (2016—) |- | 2014— | ''[[The Great British Bake Off: An Extra Slice]]'' | Presenter | 4 series |- | 2015 | ''[[The Great British Bake Off#The Great Sport/Comic Relief Bake Off|The Great Comic Relief Bake Off]]'' | Presenter | One episode (25 February) |- | 2016 | ''[[Sport Relief 2016|Jo Brand's Hell of a Walk for Sport Relief]]'' | Herself | One-off episode (17 March) |- | 2016— | ''Going Forward''{{cn|date=May 2016}} | Kim Wilde | Also written by Brand |- | 2016 | ''[[The Dog Rescuers#The Kitten Rescuers|The Kitten Rescuers]]'' | Presenter | One-off episode |- | 2017— | ''Jo Brand's Cats & Kittens'' | Presenter | 1 series |- | 2018— | ''Britain’s Best Junior Doctors'' | Presenter | 1 series |} ;TV guest appearances *''[[Never Mind the Buzzcocks]]'' (1998, 1999) *''[[School's Out (TV series)|School's Out]]'' (2007) *''[[Would I Lie to You? (TV series)|Would I Lie to You?]]'' (2009, 2014, 2015, 2017) *''[[Play It Again]]'' (2007) *''[[The Jonathan Ross Show]]'' (2013, 2016) *''[[Five Minutes to a Fortune]]'' (2013) *''[[Fifteen to One|Celebrity Fifteen to One]]'' (2013) *''[[Catchphrase (UK game show)|Catchphrase: Celebrity Special]]'' (2014) *''[[Tipping Point: Lucky Stars]]'' (2014){{cite web|author=7.45pm – 8.45pm|url=http://www.itv.com/presscentre/ep8week35/tipping-point-lucky-stars|title=Tipping Point: Lucky Stars Episode 8 | presscentre|publisher=Itv.com|date=13 August 2014|accessdate=26 August 2014}} *''[[The Million Pound Drop]]'' (2015) *''[[Sunday Night at the Palladium]]'' (2015) *''[[Travel Man]]'' (2016) *''[[John Bishop: In Conversation With...]]'' (2016) ;Film {| class="wikitable" style="border="2" |- style="text-align:center;" ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Notes |- | 1999 | ''[[Human Traffic]]'' | Reality | |- | 2011 | ''[[Horrid Henry: The Movie]]'' | Greasy Greta/Demon Dinner Lady | |- | 2017 | ''[[Peppa Pig|Peppa Pig: My First Cinema Experience]]'' | Mrs. Crocodile | Segment: The Zoo |- | 2018 | ''The More You Ignore Me'' | Sandra | |} ==Stand-up DVDs== * ''Barely Live'' (24 November 2003) ==Awards and nominations== * [[British Comedy Award]] 1992: Top comedy club performer * [[British Comedy Award]] 1995: Best stand-up comic * [[British Comedy Award]] 2010: Best female TV comic * [[BAFTA]] 2011: Best Female Performance in a Comedy Role * [[British Comedy Award]] 2012: Best female TV comic ==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs= {{Cite book|last=Brand|first=Jo|title=Look Back in Hunger: The Autobiography|publisher=Headline Book Publishing|year=2009|pages=|isbn=0-7553-5524-5}} {{Citation|last=Vincent|first=Sally|title=Kicking off the bovver boots|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|date=8 May 2004|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2004/may/08/comedy.fiction|accessdate=4 May 2010|location=London}} {{Citation|last=Geear|first=Jo|title=Jo Brand: a Kentish maid|newspaper=''BBC Kent''|publisher=BBC|date=23 August 2005|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/kent/content/articles/2005/08/23/jo_brand_lifestyle_feature.shtml|accessdate=4 May 2010}} {{Citation|last=Atkins|first=Tom|title=20 Questions With ... Jo Brand|newspaper=What's On Stage|publisher=Bandwidth Communications Ltd|date=25 February 2008|url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/index.php?pg=207&story=E8821203683281|accessdate=4 May 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616054349/http://www.whatsonstage.com/index.php?pg=207&story=E8821203683281|archivedate=16 June 2011|df=dmy-all}} }} ==External links== {{Commons category|Jo Brand}} * {{IMDb name|0104476}} * [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2008/01/30/btbrand130.xml Jo Brand: Me? Singing? I couldn't get arrested?] Interview by Jasper Rees, ''The Telegraph'', 30 January 2008. * [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/main.jhtml?xml=/health/2005/04/09/hrun09.xml Keep on running: Jo Brand] Interview by Tarquin Cooper, ''The Telegraph'', 9 April 2005. * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/speaker/about/judges/jo_brand.shtml Article about Brand's career] for TV show ''The Speaker'', BBC website * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8202317.stm BBC Interview by Matt Stadlen] – Five Minutes With: Jo Brand (2009-08-14) {{British Academy Television Award for Best Female Comedy Performance}} {{Women's Equality Party (UK)|state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Brand, Jo}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century British comedians]] [[Category:20th-century English actresses]] [[Category:21st-century British comedians]] [[Category:21st-century English actresses]] [[Category:21st-century women writers]] [[Category:Actresses from Kent]] [[Category:Actresses from London]] [[Category:Alumni of Brunel University]] [[Category:BAFTA winners (people)]] [[Category:BBC people]] [[Category:British feminists]] [[Category:Comedians from London]] [[Category:English autobiographers]] [[Category:English non-fiction writers]] [[Category:English nurses]] [[Category:English stand-up comedians]] [[Category:English television actresses]] [[Category:English television presenters]] [[Category:English television writers]] [[Category:English women comedians]] [[Category:Feminist artists]] [[Category:Labour Party (UK) people]] [[Category:People educated at Tunbridge Wells Girls' Grammar School]] [[Category:People from Hastings]] [[Category:People from Wandsworth]] [[Category:Socialist feminists]]
